head.title: No Cheer for the Home Team

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance

hedline.hl1: No Cheer for the Home Team

abstract.p: Former Dell Computer chief financial officer Thomas J Meredith raises more than $800,000 from Democrats at his Austin, Tex, home, with help from Pres Clinton; fellow fund-raiser Roy Spence call Meredith's willingness to raise money for party of Texas Gov George W Bush's rival 'a brave thing'; Meredith replies, 'When you got a billion dollars, you can be brave.' (M)

block.p: Rooting for Al Gore and the Democrats in Texas these days can be as dangerous as rooting for the 49ers at a Dallas Cowboys home game. Especially when your boss is Michael Dell, an ardent Republican.

But on Monday night, Thomas J. Meredith, the former chief financial officer of Dell Computer and now a managing director of the Dell Ventures unit, raised more than $800,000 for the Democrats at his home in Austin, with the help of President Clinton. Roy Spence, a founder of Austin's GSD & M advertising agency, now owned by Omnicom, raised an additional $125,000 or so at his home.
Rooting for Al Gore and the Democrats in Texas these days can be as dangerous as rooting for the 49ers at a Dallas Cowboys home game. Especially when your boss is Michael Dell, an ardent Republican.

But on Monday night, Thomas J. Meredith, the former chief financial officer of Dell Computer and now a managing director of the Dell Ventures unit, raised more than $800,000 for the Democrats at his home in Austin, with the help of President Clinton. Roy Spence, a founder of Austin's GSD & M advertising agency, now owned by Omnicom, raised an additional $125,000 or so at his home.
Reflecting on Mr. Meredith's willingness to raise money for the party of George W. Bush's rival, Mr. Spence recalls telling him, ''That's a brave thing.''
Mr. Meredith, noting his circumstances, replied, according to Mr. Spence: ''When you got a billion dollars, you can be brave.''

In seeking to recruit employees, Mr. Spence's Web site, gsdm.com, asks visitors if they are creative. Click ''yes'' and you get a fill-in-the-blanks application letter. Click ''no'' and you end up at www.irs.gov.
